description: From Anglo-Norman caucie, chaucee et al., from Late Latin calceāta. In Guernsey use after Guernsey Norman cauchie.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An embankment holding in water; a dam. [14th–18th c.]
(now dialectal) A causeway across marshy ground, an area of sea etc.
examples: than com Soriondes with all his peple that was so grete, and sette ouer the cauchie so rudely as horse myght renne.

entries.meaning: (now dialectal) A paved path or highway; a street, or the part of a street paved with paving or cobbles as opposed to flagstones.
